title: 109_s3680
content: The Act is titled the "Securing Equity for the Economic Development of Low Income Areas Act of 2006" and defines terms such as "Administration," "low-income geographic area," "New Markets Venture Capital company," and "New Markets Venture Capital Program." It also focuses on expanding the New Markets Venture Capital Program. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to require the Administrator to select companies from each geographic region for the New Markets Venture Capital Program. The Administrator's participation in the program is now mandatory. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to require the Administrator to select companies from each geographic region for the New Markets Venture Capital Program. The Administrator must now enter into small manufacturer participation agreements, with at least one agreement being with a company primarily involved in small manufacturer development and investment. The Administrator can decline to enter into a participation agreement with a company not primarily engaged in small manufacturer development and investment. The Administrator will submit a report to Congress evaluating the success of the New Markets Venture Capital Program in promoting economic development in low-income areas. Additionally, an Office of New Markets Venture Capital will be established under the Small Business Investment Act of 1958. The Office of New Markets Venture Capital is established in the Investment Division of the Administration, headed by a Director appointed by the Administrator. The Director's responsibilities include administering the New Markets Venture Capital Program, assessing and advising on program changes, and expanding participation of small business concerns. The Office of New Markets Venture Capital Program aims to encourage investment in small manufacturing and perform other related duties as assigned by the Administrator. SEC. 6. LOW-INCOME GEOGRAPHIC AREAS. Modification of the definition of low-income geographic area for the New Markets Venture Capital Program under the Small Business Investment Act of 1958, aligning it with the definition in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for the new markets tax credit. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 has been amended to apply to private capital raised under section 354(d)(1) before, on, or after the date of enactment. A study on the availability of equity capital in low-income areas is required to be conducted by the Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Administration within 180 days, with a report to be submitted to Congress within 90 days after completion of the study. The Administrator will make recommendations based on a study conducted on the availability of equity capital in low-income areas. SEC. 7 amends the time limit for final approval of companies under the Small Business Investment Act. SEC. 8 requires the Administrator to create standard application documents for New Markets Venture Capital Program within 60 days. SEC. 9 pertains to operational assistance grants. SEC. 9 of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to provide operational assistance grants to New Markets Venture Capital companies. The grant amount will be 10% of private capital raised by the company or $1,000,000, whichever is less. SEC. 10 of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 authorizes appropriations for the New Markets Venture Capital Program for fiscal years 2006 through 2009. $1,000,000 is authorized for the Office of New Markets Venture Capital to carry out section 202 of the Act.
